documents.title: that 's everything from simon
text: thanks so much to simon for his answers to your questions .
his translation of the medieval english poem pearl is published this month by faber .
look out next week for webchats with louis theroux and underworld , announced in the coming days .

documents.title: on austerity : 'we are being silenced and erased '
text: raoulchateaubriand asks : i worry what long-term effects ( as well as short-term ) the austerity policies of this government will have on the wellbeing of the nation .
things like the arts seem to be relegated more than ever .
i would be interested to hear your take on what effect you think all this might be having on today 's poets and on the poets of the future .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:41pm i worry about that too .
a lot .

the museums and libraries in the valleys around the west riding are being closed or handed over to volunteers because of lack of funding , and the local structures - physical and otherwise - are being left to rot .
our cultural venues and proud public buildings are not treasure houses and tourist attractions as they are in some of the big cities , but storehouses of identity and community and belonging .
someone earlier in the day asked me what makes me passionate - i feel passionate about this .
i feel as if by taking away those institutions our inheritance is being closed down and we are being silenced and erased .
purpleshark asks : walking home is an inspirational read and audiobook .
what are the plans for recording more of your work i.e .
all points north ( please !
) , seeing stars ( again yes please ! ) .
subject to no dodgy back ( and a good supply of diclofenac ) when is the next walk ?
( keen to join the taxomomy of fellow hikers ! )

guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:36pm there was a plan to record walking away but in the end i could n't bear to sit in a small sound-proofed room for three days listening to the sound of my own voice .
they were threatening to find someone else to read it maybe one of those other simon armitages - keep things simple .
throthelookingglass asks : how 's your dad peter doing ?
i worked with him at ashton [ also was at his retirement do ] : ) guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:34pm he 's good .
and happy , like all retired probation officers .

documents.title: 'oxford definitely needs to work harder in admitting people from state schools '
text: oxford university , where armitage is professor of poetry .
/getty images tom black asks : does oxbridge strangle uk culture ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:32pm in my view it definitely needs to work harder in admitting people from state schools .
everyone i 've spoken to at oxford ( admittedly i 've only been there six months ) seems to want to do something about it but nobody appears to have a firm plan of action .
to my mind it 's about recognising potential .
most applicants would seem to have the required qualifications ( ie a clean sweep of top grades ) but get filtered out at interview why ?

documents.title: 'morrissey gave me a look that would curdle milk '
text: ewanbarr asks about simon 's band : did morrissey ever tell you what he thinks of the scaremongers ?
i remember that when you interviewed him for the guardian a few years ago , you hid a cd in the book of poetry you gave him .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:30pm the look on his face as he turned to leave said it all .
a look that would curdle milk , as they say .
but it 's nice to think of it blasting out of his car as he cruises the streets of la with a sinatra in the passenger seat .
siobhan007 asks : dear mr armitage , i really liked your poem the manhunt , and i wondered if you found it easy to write it from the point of view of the wife ?
would you say that you are sending an anti-war message in your poetry , or concentrating more on the individual tragedies resulting from war , or both ?
also , i 'm intrigued by the title of this poem as it usually suggests something very aggressive , and yet here the wife 's attitude is very tentative .
could you say why you chose this title ?
is it to suggest that the poor man is so badly hurt mentally and physically that even being close to his own wife is as difficult as being the object of a manhunt ?
thank you .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:28pm the poem is taken from a film i made with director brian hill called the not dead , about war veteran suffering from ptsd .
eddie had served as a peace keeper in bosnia and had struggled to reintegrate with life back at home .

but i wanted a woman 's voice in the film , to speak from the perspective of someone dealing with those traumas , so i wrote the poem in the voice of laura , eddie 's wife , who narrates the journey of bullet that hit eddie in the side of the face and finished up somewhere in his chest .
the title comes from the idea that she is searching for her husband , the one she knew previously and was trying to rescue .

joe bradbury asks : the sonnets in book of matches are meant to be read in the same amount of time it would take for a match to be lit and burn out will cook 's matches do or will this ruin the overall rhythm and flow of the work ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:25pm cook 's matches are best , especially if you 're a slow reader .
but a sparkler would be an interesting variation .
kamski asks : what inspired your poem back in the early days of the twenty-first century ' ?
is it in any way an attempt to give a voice to a mumbai street-seller ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:24pm i bought a balloon from a mumbai street seller - it was an embarrassing act of patronage and it backfired .
there 's guilt in that poem .

lordbasil asks : simon , i was born & grew up in marsden & am roughly the same age as you - i found it a magical place to inhabit as a young kid and it developed my love of the outdoors & the emotions it can stir within - what effect did this place have on you & did it inspire & influence your work ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:23pm i think of it now as a place deserving of its own hand-drawn map on the inside cover of a hard-back fantasy novel .
drwhatson asks : were you the one who took the catch ?
one of my favourite poems by the way .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:22pm i was .
it never got better than that .
later on i became a wicket-keeper more fun and more involving , but it insulated me from the physicality of the world by the thickness of the pimpled gloves and the wet chamois inners .
some of the old school stumpers reportedly slipped a slice of steak inside their gloves to soften the blows highly tenderized after fifty overs i would have thought but i never tried it .
globalviewpoint asks : what word rhymes with orange ?
you 're a poet , you should know !
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:21pm nothing rhymes with orange .
no it does n't .
elinhanff asks : as a nine year old child i wrote ( among many other things ) a whole cycle of poems about the birth of christ .
and was allowed to read them aloud to the form below mine .
can you beat this for utter ghastliness ?
please say yes .
if necessary , lie .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:20pm i 'm reluctant to criticise - you might have inadvertently created a new cycle of mystery plays .
hootsmon asks : what is your favourite limerick ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:18pm it 's the one about a bishop from birmingham , unrepeatable here .
i have to say also that i 've always had a lot of respect for the lyrics of hitler has only got one ball as sung to the colonel bogey march .
not a limerick as such but a truly enterprising rhyme scheme and heartfelt language .

documents.title: beyonce ? 'a goddess to her generation '
text: on beyonce : i do like the song where she gets a big freak on at the end ' .
devaney/gc images plymgary asks : what are your thoughts on beyonce ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:15pm i 've heard the new album about fifty times coming through the wall of my daughter 's bedroom .
beyonce is a goddess to her generation .

so it 's been something of a soundtrack in this house over the last few weeks i 'd say i 've absorbed it as much as appreciated it , but i do like the song where she gets a big freak on at the end and gives hubby a final warning .
i 'm told she flings forth her wedding ring in the video .
kbg541 asks : what does a poet do all day ?
larkin suggested that no poets could reasonably writer for more than two hours a day - and spend the rest of it getting into trouble .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:11pm amateur taxidermy ?
runnel asks : seeing him as a literary figure has even led some minor poets- simon armitage , who he ? - to write condescending appreciations ' of his art from a supposedly empathetic position .
but then , as nietszche well knew , commmunication is only possible between equals . '

- from revolution in the air : the songs of bob dylan 1957-1973 , by clinton heylin , 2009 on reading this i knew who you were , you were the man i 'd listened to as a lad who read poems on the mark radcliffe show , sentences like not skin but rind in a particular tone which stopped me doing what i was doing on a late evening .
i wondered what you made of this broadside and here , if it 's not too impertinent , is my chance to ask .

guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:09pm see , this is the problem with live web-chat things or whatever it is i 'm doing right now , because i 'm tempted to write something like , which i guess rules out any meaningful communication between bob dylan and clinton heylin phnaw phnaw and then wish i had n't .
flattering , though , to have nietszche wheeled in against you .
as if i should counter with moses or lawrence from felt .
`` let the snakes crinkle their heads to death ``
xanthe asks : would you advise an ( almost ) unpublished poet to self publish ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:07pm yes , but try to find some editorial supervision as well .
maciver asks : how are your feet holding up ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:06pm they 're fine , though they flinch at the idea of another long walk .

documents.title: 'parenthesis by david jones is the greatest modernist poem of the twentieth century , greater than the waste land '
text: dis1ney asks : which contemporary welsh poet , writing in english and still alive , would you recommend to a reader ?
( other than gillian clarke ) .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:05pm actually can i recommend a dead one ?
david jones , especially his long poem in parenthesis .
a poem of ww1 but not published until twenty years later .
the greatest modernist poem of the twentieth century in my opinion , greater than the waste land ( and with better notes ! ) .
it culminates in mametz wood , in picardie , with the queen of the woods bequeathing gifts to the dead and dying and soldier john ball looking to lay down his weapon .
i stood in that wood last friday ( trespassing , in several respects ) , pinned my great uncle 's medals to a young oak and brought back a flower for my wife , whose family are welsh .
donald j makin asks : when i was called a poet i did not like the term as i felt it was sissy and all poets did was wonder round writing about love and feelings .
your poetry changed that .
when or how did you know you were poet ?
was there a decision that right am a poet or was it more organic ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:03pm from reading ted hughes when i was about fifteen i knew poetry was going to be my thing .
reading it rather than writing it , but a secret thing , a refuge , a place to go where others would n't follow .
if everyone had been interested in it then i would n't - and that 's probably still the case .
if you want to call yourself a poet just do it - you do n't have to wear a big purple hat to prove it .
but when other people refer to you as a poet , perhaps that 's when the title becomes legitimately conferred .
people in the centre of sheffield there 's real tradition of poetry in public places in the city ' .
paperbookworm asks : hi simon , there are poems on walls and banners ( yours ) all over sheffield .
do you think as sheffield uni poetry prof you could organise them into a book and maybe add some more ?
your biggest fan in sheffield .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 2:00pm yes there 's real tradition of poetry in public places in the city , both authorised and otherwise .

i 've just come out of a meeting where we 've been discussing the possibility of writing a poem on the surface of a public place - the wall of a building or the paving stones of a piazza - that only becomes visible after rain , through the application of teflon to the stencilled area .
or sowing a poem into field , which becomes legible as the crops grow .
and the first year i was in post here we sent a poem into space .
crazyguy asks : what inspired the poem book of matches ?
it sounds like it describes a period of turmoil in your life .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:58pm it 's fair to say i was n't at my most level-headed .
the sequence takes its structure from a party game , and one that 's been hijacked by analysts .
a respondent is asked to strike a match then tell the story of their life before the match goes out .
i 've always been interested what people will blurt out under the pressure of the flame moving slowly towards the fingertips .
each of the poems is titled with an asterisk yet another matchstick flaring into life , allowing the speaker another attempt at expression .

most of the first lines in the poems are taken verbatim from a character assessment questionnaire i had to hand out at work at the time ( i was a probation officer in manchester ) ie i am very bothered when i think of the bad things i have done in my life .
useful provocations for poems .
cookiejar asks : do you find huddersfield depressing ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:55pm it depends who 's asking the question .
if you 're from hampstead no , it 's an earthly paradise of uninterrupted delights .
if you 're from huddersfield there 's room for negotiation .
poliomaldini asks : what 's your lovely cousin claire up to now ?
worked with her in bristol and she used to bring the most amazing pasties back from cornwall .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:54pm she got married to keith .
as i walked towards the podium for my first oxford lecture i put my hand in my suit pocket and pulled out a smithereen of confetti from their wedding day .

documents.title: on twitter : 'privacy is the new black '
text: i probably do n't need this in my life ' twitter .
neal/afp/getty images littlshyninman asks : you do n't seem to be a user of twitter .
your near-contemporary and fellow yorkshireman ian mcmillan uses it to great effect , tweeting impressions from his early morning stroll .
are you not tempted to use social media to get poetry to a wider audience ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:51pm i do n't use any social media , and i 'll probably regret doing this today .
not sure why .
someone said the other week , i thought if any poet had a twitter account it would be you .
maybe that 's the reason .
i 've always thought of poetry as an act of communication , but at a considered distance .
also , on the very few occasions i 've looked at feeds and pages from other writers sorry to say this they 've always smacked of neediness and self-promotion .
plus , it 's too late to start now .
privacy is the new black .
i once guest-tweeted for sheffield university for a week .
the first reply ( reply ? )
i looked at said , is you that bum hole wot i done in english .
i thought , i probably do n't need this in my life .
legomaniac asks : what message would you give to gcse students who are reluctant to access poetry because it is too hard ' ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:49pm do n't think of it as a riddle .
to begin with , talk about it from a personal point of view .
what does it make you think , feel , remember .
get a highlighter pen and mark the interesting words .
turn them to neon .
orange or green works best .

documents.title: 'wisdom is death to the contemporary poet '
text: littlshyninman asks : when you started out with books like zoom !
and kid , you made a big impression for being honest and original - your style used the no-nonsense northern vernacular and your subject was ordinary people doing ordinary things .
nowadays you 're oxford professor of poetry and translate sir gawain and the green knight .
do you still identify with the young poet who wrote about skimming stones and moving furniture or have you discarded him in favour of loftier pursuits ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:47pm in my early twenties i was carefree , naã¯ve and irresponsible , useful preconditions for an entry into poetry .
i still carry versions of those attitudes with me , but i 'd be worried if i had n't learned , changed , developed , grown etc .
the one crucial thing for me is never to lose a sense a wonder and curiosity i still see myself as someone who asks rather than tells , someone with a child-like eye on the world .
wisdom is death to the contemporary poet .
lukebenni asks : hello mr armitage , i 'm just from over the hill in uppermill .
i was just pondering , how did you start to get your work out before you became a published poet ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:45pm you have a lovely viaduct there .
i always see you , uppermill , from the air .
i went to poetry workshops then started sending poems to small magazines .
with a stamped addressed envelope for their return .
the idea was to build up a manuscript that carried the credentials of a publishing history .
not sure if this still applies , but ca n't think of another way of doing it .
pinkroom asks : why did you spoil all those lovely , timeless , rocks in yorkshire with your poems ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:44pm you 're talking about the six stanza stones poems .
three of the stones were introduced into the landscape , and two of the others had already been exposed and brutalised by quarrying .
it makes me think you have n't actually seen them .
people have been going to those moors for millennia to carve their dreams and desires into the stone , usually to an audience of stars , sheep and gods .
mine is a very small part of that dialogue and had the blessing and support of all the guardians and groups who oversee those areas .
but i 'm sorry if i 've spoiled something for you , it was n't my intention .
spoil is an interesting word , is n't it , in relation to the earth ?
cuniculus asks : do you read modern poets in any other languages ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:42pm yes but only in translation , which is embarrassing , i know , and a great frustration .
like many others hereabouts i 'm the butt of the joke that goes , `` what 's the word for someone who speaks two languages : bilingual .
what 's the word for someone who speaks one : english . ''
some people have claimed i do n't even speak english .
but it probably takes more than an elementary understanding of a foreign tongue to experience poetry properly - poetry being the language within the language etc .
grundistled asks : i used to receive mail for a previous occupant when i lived in a rented house in sheffield - a mr simon armitage - i 've always wondered if it was you .
did you used to live in a very poky terrace in sandhurst place , crookes ?

guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:39pm i used to receive mail for a previous occupant when i lived in a rented house in sheffield - a mr simon armitage - i 've always wondered if it was you .
did you used to live in a very poky terrace in sandhurst place , crookes ?
i did n't , as far as i remember .
unless it was a cheque for a vast sum of money , in which case yes , it was me .
i think there are at least three simon armitages in huddersfield alone , but i 'm yet to meet any of them .
armitage is a pretty common name in west yorkshire .
i was in the somme last weekend , mooching around cemeteries and monuments to the fallen .
many armitages there , but i did n't see a simon ( though i did find a w shakespeare , in flatiron copse cemetery ) .
leanne yauu asks : what has been the most unusual source of inspiration for your poems so far ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:36pm i 've been writing a sequence of poems about a new cemetery at the top of the road .
i did n't see that coming ( the cemetery or the poems ) .

documents.title: on song lyrics : 'la la la is sometimes perfect '
text: lotusblue asks : if you were to compile a book of song lyrics that could pass for poetry , which three songs would you put in that book and why ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:35pm i 've always made a distinction between song lyric and poetry .
they 're rarely the same thing , even if they share the medium of language and similar techniques .
song lyrics are delivered on things called tunes , which supply atmosphere and mood etc .
poems have to supply all those things through language alone .
that 's not to diminish song-writers it 's a specialised art and a difficult one .
good songwriters know that la la la is sometimes perfect .
good poets know it never is .

yasminiemouse asks : my as level english literature class have been studying your poem chainsaw versus the pampas grass ' for our exam in 2 weeks and i would love to know your thoughts on gender inequality ?

i 'd also like to know whether you purposefully presented the chainsaw as man because you feel that the male population are still ( to this day ) as seen as the more dominant , vigorous sex or if you presented the chainsaw as violent to reflect the stereotype that all ' men are seen as superior ' .
thoughts ? ? ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:33pm gender inequality ?
i 'm against it .
marcus hoffman asks : would you accept the role of poet laureate if it was offered or turn it down ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:31pm what are the hours ?

documents.title: on influences : 'the h section of the bookshelf gets a lot of hammer : hardy , hughes , harrison , heaney , hill ( selima and geoffrey ) , homer '
text: first and foremost and always ' ted hughes .
/ap louie e bell asks : which poets were you influenced by ?
( i always keep the collected hardy by my bedside ) guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:27pm i have a big hardy next to the bed as well .
it 's a great pattern-book , for choosing shapes .
the h section of the bookshelf gets a lot of hammer : hughes ( first and foremost and always , harrison , heaney , hill ( selima and geoffrey ) ¦homer .
and gunn , plath , lowell , bishop , they came in at the beginning , then i started moving backwards in time , the ww1 poets , hardy , yeats , the victorians , the romantics , the anonymous .
two books were really important for me : a school anthology called voices poems , interviews and photographs of the poets ( except hughes there was a of a black cliff face instead ! )
anyone remember voices ( ed geoffrey summerfield ) ?
and a big fat anthology of american verse , to turn my head in another direction .
davidcrane asks : do you feel a sort of psychic rivalry with ted hughes ?
the thought crossed my mind , reading one of your stanza stones poems on a bleak day above the aire valley .
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:24pm in that staring competition i think i 'd be the first to blink .

documents.title: on passion : 'the sunday times once said i 'd exploded in an interview i think i put my teaspoon down '
text: debbichelsea asks : what are you most passionate about ?

guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:22pm i can become embarrassingly passionate in regard to major ( and in fact minor ) sporting events though my allegiances are complex and contradictory .
i do n't like vagueness though i do n't remember getting overheated about it .
a journalist at the sunday times once said i 'd exploded in an interview in actual fact i think i put my teaspoon down and looked into the distance for a moment or so .
yeats warns us against passionate intensity , which the worst of us are full of .

michaelmolyneux again , with this question : do you not think that poets have an obligation to tackle the big philosophical questions - existence , reality , the human condition - rather than merely sketching the quirkiness of humdrum british life ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:20pm i take it from your question that you see me as a mere sketcher of humdrum british life .
i do n't mind and i do n't suppose larkin or shakespeare or most of the poets i admire would either .
i 've always thought that the larger universal themes are better addressed through details and examples .
most attempts at tackling the big philosophical questions ( and most poetic obligations come to that ) end in bloated pretentiousness or vacuous over-reaching .
or boredom .
sketch is an interesting word here british and irish poets are particularly adept at sketch writing little scenes of human activity the curtains open , the poem does its thing the curtains close .

michaelmolyneux asks : as a rough percentage , how many writers today do you think seek to enhance their ability to see the world more sharply , stripping consciousness bare using techniques such as meditation ?
or do you see poetry as more as a craft than a spiritual pursuit ?
guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:18pm roughly 37.5 % .

documents.title: simon has begun
text: simon is now answering your questions live .
first up is this from tristan moss there is probably more poetry being published now than ever before , in online journals , magazines , pamphlets , collections and anthologies .
do you think that the majority of it is good poetry ?
or would you agree with clive james that there is good and bad poetry and to much of what is published today is close to being good ?

guardian contributor simonarmitage 04 may 2016 1:16pm i think it 's probably easier these days to produce poetry , by way of word processing , and easier to disseminate poetry , by way of the internet .
whether that counts as writing it ' and publishing it ' i 'm not sure .
i think a more interesting question is whether the number of readers have increased .
i like about one poem in every dozen i read .
maybe less .
it 's ok not to like all poems .

documents.title: post your questions for simon armitage
text: with his ruminations on everything from humdrum british life to ancient greece and the horrors of war , simon armitage is one of britain 's best-known poets .

his work rate is staggering , combining readings with film-making , radio programmes , songwriting , stage productions , teaching at sheffield university , and , following in the footsteps of auden and heaney , lecturing as oxford professor of poetry .

as well as new poems reflecting on aerial photographs of the somme , his latest work is pearl , a translation of a medieval epic thought to be by the same anonymous author of sir gawain and the green knight , which armitage has also translated to much acclaim .
with pearl published this month , armitage joins us to answer your questions about anything in his hugely varied career , in a live webchat from 1.15pm bst onwards on wednesday 4 may .
post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .
